description: From Middle French classe, from Latin classis (“a class or division of the people, assembly of people, the whole body of citizens called to arms, the army, the fleet, later a class or division in general”), from Proto-Indo-European *kelh₁- (“to call, shout”). Doublet of clas and classis.

examples: To talented authors Tim Ash and Brian Reich for introducing me to John Wiley & Sons—a truly class outfit.

entries.meaning: (countable) A group, collection, category or set sharing characteristics or attributes.
examples: The new Ford Fiesta is set to be best in the 'small family' class.
That is one class-A heifer you got there, sonny.
Often used to imply membership of a large class.
This word has a whole class of metaphoric extensions.

entries.meaning: (sociology, countable) A social grouping, based on job, wealth, etc. In Britain, society is commonly split into three main classes: upper class, middle class and working class.
(uncountable) The division of society into classes.
examples: Jane Austen's works deal with class in 18th-century England.
Apologizing for losing your temper, even though you were badly provoked, showed real class.

entries.meaning: (education, countable and uncountable) A group of students in a regularly scheduled meeting with a teacher.
examples: The class was noisy, but the teacher was able to get their attention with a story.

entries.meaning: A series of lessons covering a single subject.
examples: I took the cooking class for enjoyment, but I also learned a lot.

entries.meaning: (countable) A group of students who commenced or completed their education during a particular year. A school class.
examples: The class of 1982 was particularly noteworthy.

entries.meaning: (countable) A category of seats in an airplane, train or other means of mass transportation.
examples: I used to fly business class, but now my company can only afford economy.

entries.meaning: (taxonomy, countable) A rank in the classification of organisms, below phylum and above order; a taxon of that rank.
examples: Magnolias belong to the class Magnoliopsida.
It is the class of Italian bottled waters.

entries.meaning: (statistics) A grouping of data values in an interval, often used for computation of a frequency distribution.
(set theory) A collection of sets definable by a shared property.
examples: The class of all sets is not a set.
Every set is a class, but classes are not generally sets. A class that is not a set is called a proper class.

entries.meaning: (military) A group of people subject to be conscripted in the same military draft, or more narrowly those persons actually conscripted in a particular draft.

(object-oriented programming, countable) A set of objects having the same behavior (but typically differing in state), or a template defining such a set in terms of its common properties, functions, etc.
One of the sections into which a Methodist church or congregation is divided, supervised by a class leader.

verbs.description: class (third-person singular simple present classes, present participle classing, simple past and past participle classed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To assign to a class; to classify.
examples: I would class this with most of the other mediocre works of the period.
the genus or family under which it classes

entries.meaning: (transitive) To divide into classes, as students; to form into, or place in, a class or classes.
